column2: Over 7,000 rare genetic disorders affect 400 million people worldwide, with 72% being genetic in origin. Conditions like cystic fibrosis, Huntington's disease, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy stem from specific gene mutations. Diagnosis often takes 5-7 years due to symptom variability. Breakthroughs in gene therapy (like Luxturna for inherited blindness) and CRISPR gene editing offer hope—Zolgensma for spinal muscular atrophy costs $2.1 million per treatment but prevents progressive paralysis. The Orphan Drug Act incentivizes research, with 500+ orphan drugs approved since 1983. Challenges include exorbitant treatment costs and limited specialist access. Genetic counseling helps families understand inheritance patterns, while newborn screening programs enable early intervention for treatable disorders like PKU.
column3: How many rare genetic disorders are currently identified?
column6: Over 7,000

column2: Cardiometabolic disorders—including type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis—account for 20 million deaths annually. Insulin resistance links these conditions, often driven by obesity and sedentary lifestyles. The global diabetes epidemic affects 537 million adults, with 80% cases in low/middle-income countries. New GLP-1 agonists like semaglutide not only control blood sugar but also induce 15% body weight loss on average. Advanced imaging detects arterial plaque buildup before symptoms appear. Precision medicine approaches now tailor treatments based on genetic risk scores. Public health initiatives focus on sugar taxes and urban planning to increase physical activity. The economic burden exceeds $1.7 trillion yearly, with complications like kidney failure driving costs.
column3: What percentage of diabetes cases occur in developing nations?

column2: Psychiatric disorders affect 970 million people globally, with depression being the leading cause of disability. Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and OCD involve complex genetic-environmental interactions altering brain chemistry. DSM-5-TR provides diagnostic criteria, though biomarkers remain elusive for most conditions. New antidepressants like esketamine (derived from ketamine) work within hours versus weeks for SSRIs. Digital therapies—AI chatbots for CBT and VR exposure therapy—complement traditional treatments. Stigma still prevents 60% of sufferers from seeking help. The global mental health apps market will reach $26 billion by 2027. Research explores gut-brain axis connections, with probiotics showing modest benefits for anxiety. Workplace mental health programs are becoming standard among Fortune 500 companies.
column3: What is the global prevalence of psychiatric disorders?
column6: 970 million

DSM-5-TR provides diagnostic criteria, though biomarkers remain elusive for most conditions. New antidepressants like esketamine (derived from ketamine) work within hours versus weeks for SSRIs. Digital therapies—AI chatbots for CBT and VR exposure therapy—complement traditional treatments. Stigma still prevents 60% of sufferers from seeking help. The global mental health apps market will reach $26 billion by 2027. Research explores gut-brain axis connections, with probiotics showing modest benefits for anxiety. Workplace mental health programs are becoming standard among Fortune 500 companies.
column3: How quickly can esketamine alleviate depression symptoms?
column4: Within hours (vs. weeks for traditional antidepressants)
column6: New antidepressants like esketamine (derived from ketamine) work within hours versus weeks for SSRIs

column2: Infectious diseases cause 17% of global deaths annually, with COVID-19 highlighting pandemic vulnerabilities. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) threatens to make 10 million deaths yearly by 2050—current last-resort antibiotics like colistin are failing. mRNA vaccine technology (pioneered for COVID) now targets HIV, malaria, and tuberculosis. Tropical diseases—dengue, chikungunya—are expanding due to climate change altering mosquito habitats. Hospital-acquired infections (like MRSA) cost $28 billion yearly in the US alone. WHO's One Health approach connects human, animal, and environmental health to prevent outbreaks. Diagnostic advances include CRISPR-based rapid tests identifying pathogens in 30 minutes. Pandemic preparedness spending will exceed $100 billion globally by 2025.
column3: What percentage of global deaths stem from infections?

column2: Cancer causes 10 million deaths yearly, with 70% occurring in low/middle-income countries lacking screening/treatment access. Immunotherapies—checkpoint inhibitors, CAR-T cells—now achieve durable remissions for previously untreatable cancers. Liquid biopsies detect tumor DNA in blood years before imaging would show masses. The global oncology market will reach $400 billion by 2027, driven by targeted therapies. Challenges include treatment costs (CAR-T therapy averages $475,000) and immunotherapy side effects like cytokine storms. Prevention focuses on HPV vaccination (preventing cervical cancer) and tobacco control. AI now analyzes pathology slides with 98% accuracy, reducing diagnostic delays. Precision oncology matches tumor genetics to treatments, increasing survival rates for matchable patients by 30%.
column3: What percentage of cancer deaths occur in developing nations?

column2: Pediatric medicine addresses unique conditions from prematurity (affecting 1 in 10 US births) to childhood cancers (like ALL—the most common pediatric cancer). Neonatal ICUs now save 90% of infants born at 28 weeks, though long-term neurodevelopmental risks remain. Autism spectrum disorder affects 1 in 36 children, with early behavioral intervention showing significant benefits. Vaccine-preventable diseases (measles, polio) resurge in anti-vaccine hotspots. The global pediatric healthcare market will reach $14 trillion by 2027. Challenges include drug dosing complexities—75% of medications lack proper pediatric testing. Telemedicine improves specialist access for rural families. Advances like gene therapy for spinal muscular atrophy given within weeks of birth prevent disease progression entirely in some cases.
column3: What is the survival rate for 28-week preemies in NICUs?

column2: Aging-related conditions—frailty, dementia, polypharmacy—affect 15% of those over 65 globally. Sarcopenia (muscle loss) causes 50% of mobility impairments in seniors. Multimorbidity (average 4+ chronic conditions in elderly) complicates treatment. The global elderly care market will reach $2.7 trillion by 2030. Geroscience explores rapamycin and metformin to delay aging processes. Fall prevention programs reduce hip fractures by 25% through home modifications and balance training. Telemonitoring detects health declines via wearable sensors alerting caregivers. Japan leads in robotics assisting with elder care tasks. Challenges include caregiver shortages—the US needs 3.5 million more caregivers by 2030. Medicare now covers comprehensive geriatric assessments to optimize care plans.

column2: Environmental illnesses result from toxic exposures—asbestos causing mesothelioma, air pollution contributing to 7 million premature deaths yearly. Climate change expands vector-borne diseases (Lyme disease cases doubled since 2000) and heat-related illnesses. Occupational hazards like silicosis affect 30 million workers globally, mostly in developing nations. The EPA links 200+ chemicals to cancers, yet most lack adequate regulation. Treatment focuses on exposure cessation and symptom management—chelation therapy removes heavy metals. The environmental medicine market grows at 8% CAGR as awareness increases. Challenges include proving causation for legal claims—asbestos litigation exceeded $70 billion total. Prevention through policy changes (lead pipe replacements, air quality standards) proves most cost-effective long-term.
column3: How many premature deaths result from air pollution annually?
column6: 7 million

Treatment focuses on exposure cessation and symptom management—chelation therapy removes heavy metals. The environmental medicine market grows at 8% CAGR as awareness increases. Challenges include proving causation for legal claims—asbestos litigation exceeded $70 billion total. Prevention through policy changes (lead pipe replacements, air quality standards) proves most cost-effective long-term.
column3: What therapy removes heavy metals from the body?
column6: Treatment focuses on exposure cessation and symptom management—chelation therapy removes heavy metals

column2: Mitochondrial disorders are a group of rare genetic conditions affecting the energy-producing organelles in cells, impacting 1 in 5,000 individuals. These disorders often manifest as multi-system diseases with symptoms ranging from muscle weakness to neurological impairment and organ failure. Diagnosis typically involves muscle biopsies, genetic testing, and metabolic assessments. While no cure exists, treatments focus on symptom management through vitamin cocktails (like CoQ10 and riboflavin), exercise therapy, and avoiding metabolic stressors. Research breakthroughs include mitochondrial replacement therapy (three-parent IVF) to prevent disease transmission. The FDA recently approved the first mitochondrial-targeted drug, elamipretide, for specific subtypes. Challenges include phenotypic variability—even identical mutations can cause different symptoms. The global mitochondrial disease market is projected to reach $3.8 billion by 2030 as gene therapy trials progress.
column3: What cellular organelles do mitochondrial disorders affect?
column6: energy-producing organelles

column2: Dysautonomia encompasses conditions where the autonomic nervous system malfunctions, affecting 70 million people worldwide. Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) is the most common form, causing heart rate spikes upon standing. Symptoms range from fainting to gastrointestinal paralysis and temperature dysregulation. Diagnosis requires tilt-table testing and autonomic reflex screens. Treatment combines increased salt/fluid intake, compression garments, and medications like midodrine. Recent research implicates autoantibodies in many cases, leading to experimental IVIG therapy. The condition disproportionately affects young women (5:1 ratio) and often follows viral infections. COVID-19 has triggered a 300% increase in dysautonomia cases. Mobile apps now help patients track symptoms and fluid intake. The economic burden exceeds $50 billion annually in lost productivity and medical costs.
column3: Which diagnostic test confirms POTS?
column6: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome

column2: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDS) are connective tissue disorders affecting collagen production, with 13 subtypes ranging from hypermobile to vascular forms. The hypermobile type affects 1 in 5,000, causing joint instability, chronic pain, and tissue fragility. Vascular EDS carries life-threatening risks of arterial rupture. Diagnosis relies on clinical criteria and genetic testing for some subtypes. Physical therapy focusing on proprioception is first-line treatment, along with bracing and pain management. Research reveals mast cell activation contributes to inflammatory symptoms in 45% of patients. The EDS diagnostic delay averages 10-12 years due to symptom variability. Global awareness campaigns have reduced diagnosis time by 30% since 2015. Emerging treatments include TGF-β inhibitors for vascular EDS and customized 3D-printed orthotics for joint support.
column3: What protein is defective in EDS?
column6: TGF-β

column2: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS) involves inappropriate mast cell degranulation, causing multisystem allergic-type reactions without true allergies. Symptoms range from flushing and GI distress to anaphylaxis, affecting an estimated 17% of the population to varying degrees. Diagnosis requires elevated serum tryptase or urinary histamine metabolites during flares. Treatment combines H1/H2 blockers (like cetirizine and famotidine), mast cell stabilizers (cromolyn), and avoidance of triggers. Research links MCAS to 60% of idiopathic anaphylaxis cases and 40% of POTS cases. The condition often follows infections or traumatic events that 'prime' mast cells. New biomarkers like prostaglandin D2 are improving diagnostic accuracy. Specialty clinics now offer personalized histamine diets and medication protocols, reducing emergency visits by 70% for managed patients.
column3: What cells malfunction in MCAS?
column6: mast

column2: Chronic Cerebrospinal Venous Insufficiency (CCSVI) is a controversial condition where impaired venous drainage from the brain may contribute to neurological symptoms. First proposed in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, research shows 80% of MS patients have venous abnormalities versus 20% of controls. Diagnosis requires specialized Doppler ultrasound or MR venography. Treatment involves venous angioplasty to improve flow, though clinical trials show mixed results. The condition is now studied in migraine, tinnitus, and neurodegenerative diseases. Challenges include lack of standardized diagnostic criteria and insurance coverage denials. The International Society for Neurovascular Disease has established research protocols to clarify CCSVI's role. Patient-reported outcomes suggest 60% improvement in fatigue and cognition post-treatment, but more rigorous studies are needed.
column3: What imaging techniques diagnose CCSVI?
column6: specialized Doppler ultrasound or MR venography

First proposed in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, research shows 80% of MS patients have venous abnormalities versus 20% of controls. Diagnosis requires specialized Doppler ultrasound or MR venography. Treatment involves venous angioplasty to improve flow, though clinical trials show mixed results. The condition is now studied in migraine, tinnitus, and neurodegenerative diseases. Challenges include lack of standardized diagnostic criteria and insurance coverage denials. The International Society for Neurovascular Disease has established research protocols to clarify CCSVI's role. Patient-reported outcomes suggest 60% improvement in fatigue and cognition post-treatment, but more rigorous studies are needed.
column3: What treatment attempts to improve venous drainage?
column6: Treatment involves venous angioplasty to improve flow, though clinical trials show mixed results

column2: Small Fiber Neuropathy (SFN) damages unmyelinated nerve fibers, causing burning pain and autonomic dysfunction in 53 per 100,000 individuals. Diabetes accounts for only 30% of cases—the rest are idiopathic or linked to autoimmune conditions. Diagnosis requires skin biopsy showing reduced intraepidermal nerve fiber density. Treatment focuses on underlying causes and symptomatic relief with medications like gabapentin. IVIG shows promise for autoimmune-associated SFN, improving symptoms in 65% of treated patients. Research reveals 40% of fibromyalgia patients actually have SFN. New diagnostic techniques include corneal confocal microscopy detecting nerve damage. The condition increases fall risk fivefold due to impaired proprioception, prompting development of sensory-retraining physical therapy programs.
column3: What diagnostic test confirms SFN?
column4: Skin biopsy showing reduced nerve fiber density
column6: corneal confocal microscopy

column2: Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS) affects 2.5 million Americans with debilitating exhaustion, post-exertional malaise, and cognitive dysfunction. The CDC estimates only 20% of cases are diagnosed. Research implicates immune dysfunction, mitochondrial impairment, and cerebral hypoperfusion. Two-day cardiopulmonary exercise testing reveals abnormal energy metabolism in 90% of patients. Treatment focuses on pacing strategies—the controversial GET (graded exercise therapy) is now discouraged. FDA-approved drugs like low-dose naltrexone show modest symptom relief. The NIH's RECOVER Initiative is studying long COVID/ME/CFS overlaps, finding shared biomarkers like autoantibodies. Patient advocacy has secured $287 million in US research funding since 2021. Severe cases (25% of patients) are homebound, with mortality risks from cardiovascular complications.
column3: What key feature distinguishes ME/CFS fatigue?
column6: debilitating exhaustion

column2: Functional Neurological Disorder (FND) involves neurological symptoms without structural damage, accounting for 16% of neurology referrals. Symptoms include non-epileptic seizures, paralysis, or movement disorders stemming from brain network dysregulation. Diagnosis follows positive signs (like Hoover's sign for functional weakness) and absence of disease biomarkers. Treatment combines specialized physical therapy retraining movements and psychotherapy addressing contributing stressors. fMRI research shows abnormal connectivity between limbic and motor networks during symptoms. The FND Society's treatment guidelines have improved outcomes from 30% to 60% recovery rates. Public education campaigns combat stigma—YouTube videos demonstrating positive signs have 5 million views. New clinics offer intensive 5-day programs with 70% symptom improvement sustained at one year.
column3: What percentage of neurology referrals involve FND?

column2: Functional Neurological Disorder (FND) involves neurological symptoms without structural damage, accounting for 16% of neurology referrals. Symptoms include non-epileptic seizures, paralysis, or movement disorders stemming from brain network dysregulation. Diagnosis follows positive signs (like Hoover's sign for functional weakness) and absence of disease biomarkers. Treatment combines specialized physical therapy retraining movements and psychotherapy addressing contributing stressors. fMRI research shows abnormal connectivity between limbic and motor networks during symptoms. The FND Society's treatment guidelines have improved outcomes from 30% to 60% recovery rates. Public education campaigns combat stigma—YouTube videos demonstrating positive signs have 5 million views. New clinics offer intensive 5-day programs with 70% symptom improvement sustained at one year.

column2: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) causes severe limb pain after minor injuries, affecting 200,000 Americans annually. Type I (without nerve damage) accounts for 90% of cases. Symptoms include allodynia (pain from light touch), temperature asymmetry, and movement disorders. Diagnosis follows Budapest criteria assessing sensory, vasomotor, and motor signs. Treatment combines graded motor imagery, bisphosphonates, and spinal cord stimulation for refractory cases. Research shows 80% of patients have autoantibodies against autonomic receptors. The CRPS research consortium has identified three subtypes with distinct treatment responses. Early intervention within 3 months improves outcomes by 50%. Virtual reality therapy tricks the brain into perceiving pain-free movement, reducing symptoms by 40% in clinical trials.
column3: What is the hallmark pain symptom of CRPS?
column6: allodynia

column2: Post-Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome (PTLDS) affects 10-20% of Lyme patients despite antibiotic therapy, causing persistent fatigue, pain, and cognitive issues. Research suggests ongoing immune activation rather than persistent infection in most cases. Diagnostic challenges include unreliable antibody tests and overlapping symptoms with other conditions. Treatment focuses on symptom management—the controversial long-term antibiotics show no benefit in controlled trials. NIH studies reveal abnormal brain inflammation patterns on PET scans in PTLDS patients. Exercise protocols must be carefully paced to avoid post-exertional crashes. The global Lyme disease market will reach $3.1 billion by 2027 as new diagnostics (nanotrap antigen tests) and immunomodulatory treatments emerge. Patient advocacy has secured insurance coverage for multidisciplinary care in 15 US states.
column3: What percentage of Lyme patients develop PTLDS?

column2: Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva (FOP) is an ultra-rare genetic disorder (1 in 2 million) causing progressive heterotopic ossification where muscles and connective tissues turn to bone. The ACVR1 gene mutation causes bone formation in response to injury or inflammation. Diagnosis is clinical, with hallmark malformed big toes present at birth. Flare-ups often begin before age 10, frequently misdiagnosed as cancer. There is no cure, but palovarotene (a retinoic acid receptor agonist) can reduce new bone formation by 50%. The International FOP Association coordinates global research, with gene therapy trials showing promise in animal models. Patients face median survival to age 40, typically dying from restrictive chest wall syndrome. Care requires avoiding biopsies, injections, and trauma that trigger ossification. The FOP drug market is projected to reach $300 million by 2028 as new anti-inflammatory biologics enter trials.
column3: What genetic mutation causes FOP?
column6: Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva

column2: Stiff Person Syndrome (SPS) is an autoimmune CNS disorder causing progressive muscle rigidity and spasms, affecting 1-2 per million. Most patients have GAD65 antibodies attacking GABAergic neurons. Diagnosis requires EMG showing continuous motor unit activity plus antibody testing. First-line treatment is IVIG combined with benzodiazepines to enhance GABA activity. Rituximab shows 60% response rates in refractory cases. The condition often accompanies other autoimmune diseases (type 1 diabetes in 35% of patients). Severe spasms can fracture bones or cause life-threatening laryngospasms. Recent research identifies CD8+ T-cell infiltration in the spinal cord. Patient mobility declines steadily, with 75% requiring mobility aids within 5 years of diagnosis. The SPS treatment market will reach $120 million by 2027 as diagnostic awareness improves.
column3: Which antibodies are present in most SPS patients?
column6: GAD65

column2: Alkaptonuria (AKU) is a rare metabolic disorder (1 in 250,000) causing homogentisic acid accumulation due to HGD enzyme deficiency. The condition leads to ochronosis - blue-black pigmentation of cartilage and early-onset osteoarthritis (often by age 30). Diagnosis involves urine darkening upon standing and genetic testing. Nitisinone (an herbicide repurposed as medication) reduces harmful acid levels by 95%. The National AKU Centre in the UK pioneered comprehensive care including joint replacements and cardiac monitoring (40% develop valve disease). Research shows high-dose vitamin C may slow pigment deposition. Patients require specialized diets low in tyrosine/phenylalanine. The AKU Society's registry tracks 800 patients globally to improve outcomes. Without treatment, life expectancy is reduced by 10-15 years due to cardiac and renal complications.
column3: What enzyme is deficient in AKU?
column6: Alkaptonuria

The National AKU Centre in the UK pioneered comprehensive care including joint replacements and cardiac monitoring (40% develop valve disease). Research shows high-dose vitamin C may slow pigment deposition. Patients require specialized diets low in tyrosine/phenylalanine. The AKU Society's registry tracks 800 patients globally to improve outcomes. Without treatment, life expectancy is reduced by 10-15 years due to cardiac and renal complications.

column6: Nitisinone (an herbicide repurposed as medication) reduces harmful acid levels by 95%

column2: Porphyrias are a group of 8 metabolic disorders affecting heme production, with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) being the most severe (1 in 75,000). Attacks cause severe abdominal pain, neuropathy, and psychiatric symptoms triggered by certain drugs, fasting, or hormonal changes. Diagnosis requires elevated urinary porphobilinogen during attacks. Treatment involves intravenous hemin to shut down pathological heme synthesis. Givosiran, an RNAi therapeutic, reduces attack frequency by 74% in AIP patients. The American Porphyria Foundation maintains an emergency drug network. Historical theories suggest porphyria may explain the 'madness' of King George III. Patients carry 'emergency letters' to prevent misdiagnosis as drug-seeking behavior. Liver transplantation cures hepatic forms, while gene therapy trials are underway for erythropoietic types. The porphyria treatment market will exceed $500 million by 2026.
column3: What biochemical pathway is disrupted in porphyrias?
column6: heme

column2: Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a DNA repair disorder (1 in 1 million) causing extreme UV sensitivity with 10,000x higher skin cancer risk. Patients develop severe burns within minutes of sun exposure and typically die from metastatic cancer by age 20 without protection. Diagnosis involves fibroblast testing for nucleotide excision repair defects. Treatment requires total UV avoidance with protective clothing, UV-blocking window films, and night-shift lifestyles. The XP Clinic at NIH monitors 150 patients using full-body photography to detect precancers. Research explores T4 endonuclease V cream to repair UV damage and oral nicotinamide to prevent cancers. Gene therapy trials aim to restore repair enzymes. The XP Society provides 'midnight sun' camps allowing outdoor activities under blacklights. Some patients survive into their 40s with rigorous protection, though neurological degeneration affects 30%.
column3: What cellular repair system is defective in XP?
column6: Xeroderma Pigmentosum

column2: Cystinosis is a lysosomal storage disorder (1 in 100,000) causing cystine crystal accumulation in all tissues. The nephropathic form manifests in infancy with Fanconi syndrome, progressing to end-stage renal failure by age 10 without treatment. Diagnosis involves measuring leukocyte cystine levels. Cysteamine therapy depletes intracellular cystine, delaying organ damage if started early. The drug now comes in delayed-release capsules and eye drops (crystals cause photophobia). Stem cell transplantation may halt progression, while gene therapy trials are underway. The Cystinosis Research Network connects 500 families worldwide. Adults with cystinosis face complications including myopathy (60%), diabetes (30%), and pulmonary fibrosis. The average lifespan has increased from 10 to 50 years with treatment, creating new challenges in transitional care from pediatric to adult specialists.
column3: Which organ system fails first in untreated cystinosis?
column4: Kidneys (Fanconi syndrome progressing to renal failure)
column6: Stem cell transplantation

column2: Angelman Syndrome is a neurogenetic disorder (1 in 15,000) caused by UBE3A gene deficiency on chromosome 15. Characteristics include severe developmental delay, absent speech, ataxic gait ('happy puppet' movements), and seizure disorders (80% of patients). Diagnosis involves DNA methylation testing. Treatment focuses on antiseizure medications (valproate and clonazepam are most effective) and intensive behavioral therapy. Ongoing trials of gene therapy aim to restore UBE3A expression in the brain. The Foundation for Angelman Syndrome Therapeutics funds research that has reversed symptoms in mouse models. Sleep disturbances affect 90% of patients, often requiring melatonin. Adults with Angelman require lifelong care but can learn to communicate via assistive devices. The Angelman market (diagnostics and therapies) will reach $800 million by 2027 as disease-modifying treatments emerge.
column3: Which gene is deficient in Angelman Syndrome?
column6: UBE3A

column2: Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder (1 in 25,000) caused by lack of paternal genes on chromosome 15q11-13. Neonatal hypotonia transitions to hyperphagia in childhood, leading to morbid obesity if uncontrolled. Diagnosis requires genetic testing showing paternal deletion, uniparental disomy, or imprinting defects. Growth hormone therapy improves body composition and cognition. Strict food security measures are essential - some families use locking refrigerators. The Foundation for Prader-Willi Research coordinates international studies of oxytocin and GLP-1 analogs to curb appetite. Behavioral issues including skin-picking and temper outbursts require specialized interventions. Mortality rates approach 3% annually in adults due to obesity complications. The PWS treatment market is valued at $450 million, with new drugs targeting hypothalamic dysfunction in development.
column3: What chromosomal region is involved in PWS?
column6: chromosome 15q11-13

column2: Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder (1 in 25,000) caused by lack of paternal genes on chromosome 15q11-13. Neonatal hypotonia transitions to hyperphagia in childhood, leading to morbid obesity if uncontrolled. Diagnosis requires genetic testing showing paternal deletion, uniparental disomy, or imprinting defects. Growth hormone therapy improves body composition and cognition. Strict food security measures are essential - some families use locking refrigerators. The Foundation for Prader-Willi Research coordinates international studies of oxytocin and GLP-1 analogs to curb appetite. Behavioral issues including skin-picking and temper outbursts require specialized interventions. Mortality rates approach 3% annually in adults due to obesity complications. The PWS treatment market is valued at $450 million, with new drugs targeting hypothalamic dysfunction in development.
column3: Why is growth hormone therapy used?
column4: Improves body composition and cognitive function

column2: Trichotillomania (TTM) is an obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorder affecting 2% of the population, characterized by recurrent hair-pulling causing noticeable loss. The condition typically begins around puberty, with women affected 4x more than men. Diagnosis requires DSM-5 criteria including repeated attempts to stop. Treatment combines cognitive behavioral therapy (habit reversal training) and N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which reduces urges in 56% of patients. fMRI studies show abnormal connectivity in cortico-striatal circuits. The Trichotillomania Learning Center provides support groups and 'awareness bracelets'. Severe cases can lead to trichobezoars (hair balls in the gut) requiring surgery. Novel approaches include decoupling therapy (modifying pulling motions) and VR exposure to triggers. The TTM treatment market will grow to $120 million by 2026 as diagnostic awareness improves.
column3: What percentage of the population has TTM?

column2: Capillary Malformation-Arteriovenous Malformation (CM-AVM) syndrome is a genetic RASopathy (1 in 100,000) causing cutaneous vascular anomalies and risk of high-flow AVMs. Caused by RASA1 or EPHB4 mutations, diagnosis requires clinical evaluation and MR angiography to detect internal lesions. Laser therapy lightens facial port-wine stains, while embolization treats dangerous AVMs (5% of patients develop cerebral or spinal lesions). The CM-AVM Network links 300 families worldwide. Research shows mTOR inhibitors may stabilize progressing lesions. Patients require annual neurological exams and baseline brain/spine imaging. Genetic counseling is crucial as inheritance is autosomal dominant with 50% transmission risk. The vascular anomalies treatment market will reach $1.2 billion by 2027, with targeted therapies reducing invasive procedures.
column3: Which signaling pathway genes are mutated in CM-AVM?
column6: RASA1 or EPHB4

Laser therapy lightens facial port-wine stains, while embolization treats dangerous AVMs (5% of patients develop cerebral or spinal lesions). The CM-AVM Network links 300 families worldwide. Research shows mTOR inhibitors may stabilize progressing lesions. Patients require annual neurological exams and baseline brain/spine imaging. Genetic counseling is crucial as inheritance is autosomal dominant with 50% transmission risk. The vascular anomalies treatment market will reach $1.2 billion by 2027, with targeted therapies reducing invasive procedures.
